body:
### Problem

Some captures returned by `vim.treesitter.get_captures_at_cursor()` are not returned by `Query:iter_captures()`.

### Steps to reproduce

Run `nvim --clean -u minimal.lua` (assuming you have the prerequisites to install parsers for [`nvim-treesitter`](https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter)):

```lua
-- minimal.lua

for name, url in pairs {
	'https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter',
} do
	local install_path = vim.fn.fnamemodify('nvim_issue/' .. name, ':p')
	if vim.fn.isdirectory(install_path) == 0 then
		vim.fn.system { 'git', 'clone', '--depth=1', url, install_path }
	end
	vim.opt.runtimepath:append(install_path)
end

local ts = require("nvim-treesitter")

ts.setup({ install_dir = "nvim_issue/1" })
ts.install({ 'rust' }):wait(300000)

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('FileType', {
	pattern = 'rust',
	callback = function(args)
		vim.treesitter.start(args.buf, 'rust')
		vim.bo[args.buf].syntax = 'OFF'
	end
})
```

Open `foo.rs`:

```rust
fn main() { println!("{}", a.b() }) }
```

Place cursor on `b`, then run `:luafile print_captures.lua`:

```lua
-- print_captures.lua

print(vim.inspect(vim.treesitter.get_captures_at_cursor()))

local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
local lang = vim.treesitter.language.get_lang(vim.bo.filetype)
local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(bufnr, lang)
local tree = parser:parse()[1]
local query = vim.treesitter.query.get(lang, "highlights")

for id, node, _, _ in query:iter_captures(tree:root(), bufnr, 0, -1) do
	local row1, col1, _, _ = node:range()
	print(row1, col1, query.captures[id])
end
```

Output:

```
{ "variable", "variable.member", "function.call" }                     
0 0 keyword.function                                                            
0 3 variable                                                                    
0 3 function                                                                    
0 7 punctuation.bracket                                                         
0 8 punctuation.bracket                                                         
0 10 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 12 variable                                                                   
0 12 function.macro                                                             
0 19 operator                                                                   
0 19 function.macro                                                             
0 20 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 21 string                                                                     
0 25 punctuation.delimiter                                                      
0 27 variable                                                                   
0 28 punctuation.delimiter                                                      
0 29 variable                                                                   
0 30 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 31 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 33 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 34 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 36 punctuation.bracket
```

### Expected behavior

`variable.member` and `function.call` are returned by `Query:iter_captures()` at column 29.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

0.11.5

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

?

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

Ptyxis 49.2

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-256color

### Installation

System package manager

comment_data.body: You can check the source code of `get_captures_at_pos` -- look at the difference between captures and matches (`:h iter_matches`).

@clason Thanks for pointing me to its implementation. It seems like `get_captures_at_pos` also relies on `iter_captures` https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/57574db15460be27f056eb21a71b96312396a615/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua#L318

But I found that `local tree = parser:parse()[1]` is wrong, instead I have to use:

- `parser:parse(true)`
- `parser:for_each_tree()`

as follows:

```lua
local bufnr = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
local lang = vim.treesitter.language.get_lang(vim.bo.filetype)
local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(bufnr, lang)
local query = vim.treesitter.query.get(lang, "highlights")

parser:parse(true)
parser:for_each_tree(function(tstree, _)
	if not tstree then
		return
	end
	for id, node, _, _ in query:iter_captures(tstree:root(), bufnr, 0, -1) do
		local row1, col1, _, _ = node:range()
		print(row1, col1, query.captures[id])
	end
end)
```

Maybe I could add an example like this to the doc?

There is the `println!(...)` macro: https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/blob/568ede7e79172a0fe7c9d631454a97ad968deaf2/runtime/queries/rust/injections.scm#L1-L10

And for both `tree:lang()` is `rust`:

```
tree: rust
0 0 keyword.function                                                            
0 3 variable                                                                    
0 3 function                                                                    
0 7 punctuation.bracket                                                         
0 8 punctuation.bracket                                                         
0 10 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 12 variable                                                                   
0 12 function.macro                                                             
0 19 operator                                                                   
0 19 function.macro                                                             
0 20 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 21 string                                                                     
0 25 punctuation.delimiter                                                      
0 27 variable                                                                   
0 28 punctuation.delimiter                                                      
0 29 variable                                                                   
0 30 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 31 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 33 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 34 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 36 punctuation.bracket                                                        
tree: rust                                                                      
0 20 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 21 string                                                                     
0 25 punctuation.delimiter                                                      
0 27 variable                                                                   
0 28 punctuation.delimiter                                                      
0 29 variable.member                                                            
0 29 function.call                                                              
0 30 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 31 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 33 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 34 punctuation.bracket                                                        
0 35 punctuation.delimiter
```

So I think it's working as intended.
Ah, missed that, thanks! Yes, then this is working as intended.
(Better documentation is always a good idea, but I'm not sure the `iter_queries` snippet is the right place for it.)

title: Missing captures in `Query:iter_captures()`
